messages.subject: Re: homeschooling conferences
messages.msgSnippet: ... describe ... jump up and ... schooling and ... Hallelujah sister! I m in there with ya! Meghan :-)
messages.messageBody:
--- In AlwaysLearning@y..., SandraDodd@a... wrote:
>
> In a message dated 3/7/02 9:40:38 PM, moonmeghan@y...
writes:
>
> << Preaching was not the right word. I was really trying to
describe
> more of a lecture, but one that is boring and not very engaging.
>>
>
> Oh, no. I don't lecture. But I aspire to preach so that people
jump up and
> yell Hallelujah! and they throw off the shackles of demonic
schooling and
> live free in the light.
>
> Amen.

Hallelujah sister! I'm in there with ya!

Meghan :-)

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Re: homeschooling conferences
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 3/7/02 9:40:38 PM, moonmeghan@yahoo.com writes:
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 3/7/02 9:40:38 PM, moonmeghan@... writes:

<< Preaching was not the right word. I was really trying to describe
more of a lecture, but one that is boring and not very engaging. >>

Oh, no. I don't lecture. But I aspire to preach so that people jump up and
yell Hallelujah! and they throw off the shackles of demonic schooling and
live free in the light.

Amen.

messages.subject: Re: Public TV and Radio endangered
messages.msgSnippet: I sent this to a friend and he sent me back this link. Looks like this is another Urban Legend. http://urbanlegends.about.com/library/blnpr6.htm?terms=npr
messages.messageBody:
I sent this to a friend and he sent me back this link.
Looks like this is another Urban Legend.

"http://urbanlegends.about.com/library/blnpr6.htm?terms=npr"


--- In AlwaysLearning@y..., Sharon Rudd <bearspawprint@y...> wrote:
> On NPR's Morning Edition last week, Nina
> Tottenberg said that if
> the
> > Supreme Court supports Congress, it is in
> > effect the end of the National Public Radio
> (NPR), NEA & the
> Public
> > Broadcasting System (PBS).
> > PBS, NPR and the arts are facing major cutbacks
> in funding. In
> spite
> of
> > the efforts of each station to reduce spending
> > costs and streamline their services, some
> government officials
> believe
> > that the funding currently going to these
> programs is
> > too large a portion of funding for something
> which is seen as not
> > worthwhile. The only way that our representatives
> > can be aware of the base of support for PBS and
> funding for
> these
> types
> > of programs is by making our voices heard.
> > Please add your name to this list and forward
> it to friends
> who

> > be forwarded to the President and the Vice
> President of the
> United

> funding can be

messages.subject: Re: homeschooling conferences
messages.msgSnippet: ... long ... asking leading ... might be a ... Preaching was not the right word. I was really trying to describe more of a lecture, but one that is boring and
messages.messageBody:
--- In AlwaysLearning@y..., SandraDodd@a... wrote:
>
> In a message dated 3/7/02 11:41:16 AM, moonmeghan@y...
writes:
>
> << I'm pretty flexible about what format a presentation takes as
long
> as it remains interesting and I'm not 'preached' at (I'm sure that
> I'll be very content with your presentation, Sandra). >>
>

> I think the workshops are more like telling little stories and
asking leading
> questions so people think what they hadn't thought to think. It
might be a
> style of preaching.
>
> Sandra

Preaching was not the right word. I was really trying to describe
more of a lecture, but one that is boring and not very engaging.
Where you're being talked at a lot but not required to think much.
I don't have any personal experience of preaching, I used the
wrong word.

Meghan

messages.subject: Public TV and Radio endangered
messages.msgSnippet: On NPR s Morning Edition last week, Nina Tottenberg said that if the ... (NPR), NEA & the Public ... in funding. In spite of ... government officials believe
messages.messageBody:
On NPR's Morning Edition last week, Nina
Tottenberg said that if
the
> Supreme Court supports Congress, it is in
> effect the end of the National Public Radio
(NPR), NEA & the
Public
> Broadcasting System (PBS).
> PBS, NPR and the arts are facing major cutbacks
in funding. In
spite
of
> the efforts of each station to reduce spending
> costs and streamline their services, some
government officials
believe
> that the funding currently going to these
programs is
> too large a portion of funding for something
which is seen as not
> worthwhile. The only way that our representatives
> can be aware of the base of support for PBS and
funding for
these
types
> of programs is by making our voices heard.
> Please add your name to this list and forward
it to friends
who
> believe in what this stands for. This list will
> be forwarded to the President and the Vice
President of the
United
> States. This petition is being passed around the
> Internet. Please add your name to it so that
funding can be
maintained
> for NPR, PBS, & the NEA.
>
> HOW TO SIGN & FORWARD: IT'S EASY:
>
> Please keep this petition rolling. Do not
reply to me. Please
sign
> and forward to others to sign. If you prefer
> not to sign, please send to the E-mail address
indicated below.
DON'T
> WORRY ABOUT DUPLICATES.
> This is being forwarded to several people at once
to add their
names
to
> the petition. It won't matter if many people
> receive the same list as the names are being
managed. This is for
anyone
> who thinks NPR/PBS is a worthwhile
> expenditure of $1.12/year of their taxes, a
petition follows.
>
> If you sign, please forward on to others. If
not, please
don't
> kill it - send it to the Email address listed
here:
>
> wein2688@...
>
> If you happen to be the 150th, 200th, 250th,
etc., signer of
this
> petition, please forward a copy to:
>
> wein2688@...
>
> This way we can keep track of the lists and
organize them.
>
> NOTE:
> It is preferable that you SELECT (highlight) the
entirety of
this
> letter and then COPY it into a new outgoing
> message, rather than simply forwarding it.
In your new
outgoing
> message, add your name to the bottom of the list,
then
> send it on. Or if option is available, do a SEND
AGAIN.

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Re: homeschooling conferences
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 3/7/02 11:41:16 AM, moonmeghan@yahoo.com writes:
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 3/7/02 11:41:16 AM, moonmeghan@... writes:

<< I'm pretty flexible about what format a presentation takes as long
as it remains interesting and I'm not 'preached' at (I'm sure that
I'll be very content with your presentation, Sandra). >>

My dream in life is to do Jesse-Jackson-style oration.
I LOVE to listen to him. I usually have no idea what he said after it's
over, but it's a sound-massage. Probably in part because he's doing a
classic Baptist preacher cadence/rhythm/lilt/build, but he's not talking
about brimstone and hellfire.

I think the workshops are more like telling little stories and asking leading
questions so people think what they hadn't thought to think. It might be a
style of preaching.

Sandra

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] Re: homeschooling conferences
messages.msgSnippet: ... It was really our intention to camp two years ago to attend the conference - there is a KOA across town from the hotel and it s not a terrible drive.  We
messages.messageBody:
on 03/07/02 9:59 AM, moonmeghan at moonmeghan@... wrote:

> The other possibility is
> to camp somewhere within a reasonable driving distance away.
> If anyone knows of anywhere to camp, could you pass along the
> info to me, thanks.

It was really our intention to camp two years ago to attend the conference -
there is a KOA across town from the hotel and it's not a terrible drive. We
figured that it didn't matter that it was a KOA, since we'd be spending 99%
of our waking hours at the conference itself. It was however, 106 degrees!
And was only cooling down to the 90's at night!! We weenied out and got a
hotel room near the conference instead.

Jocelyn

messages.subject: Re: homeschooling conferences
messages.msgSnippet: ... would be, has ... workshop at which ... or say.  Others ... outside, anyway). I m pretty flexible about what format a presentation takes as long as it

<<<<I thought maybe it would be
> good to ask this thoughtful group for suggestions on what is,
would be, has
> been helpful to you at an in-person presentation.
>
> Different people like different things too. Some like a
workshop at which
> they're directly addressed, and given something to hold or do
or say. Others
> like anonymity where they listen in quiet stillness (on the
outside, anyway).>>>>


I'm pretty flexible about what format a presentation takes as long
as it remains interesting and I'm not 'preached' at (I'm sure that
I'll be very content with your presentation, Sandra).


<<<<> August 17-19, 2002, HSC Home=Education Conference
Sacramento, California>>>>

I'll definitely be at this one. I live about 2 hours away from
Sacramento. I'm just trying to work out if I can afford a hotel or if
I'll have to come for just one of the days. The other possibility is
to camp somewhere within a reasonable driving distance away.
If anyone knows of anywhere to camp, could you pass along the
info to me, thanks.
I'm really looking forward to meeting some of you in the flesh!

Meghan

messages.subject: Re: [AlwaysLearning] homeschooling conferences
messages.msgSnippet: ... From: SandraDodd@aol.com To: AlwaysLearning@yahoogroups.com Subject: [AlwaysLearning] homeschooling conferences Date: Wed, Mar 6, 2002, 8:56 AM August
messages.messageBody:
----------
From: SandraDodd@...
To: AlwaysLearning@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [AlwaysLearning] homeschooling conferences
Date: Wed, Mar 6, 2002, 8:56 AM


August 17-19, 2002, HSC Home=Education Conference Sacramento, California

----------



We should be at this one. I'm easy when it comes to workshops -- as long as
I'm not bored senseless (I have no worries about you in particular, but I've
been hostage in conference rooms where they could have performed emergency
dental surgery on me, as everything including my teeth had gone to sleep) I
don't have a preference for whether I listen quietly or am asked to
participate in charades, or anything in between. ;)

I don't expect to be attending many of the workshops in Sacramento (yours
for sure, others maybe when I see a schedule) -- I'll do a shift at the
county contact booth, and the girls (or at least Brit) will want to be
involved in the kids programs, so it'll be a bit of a juggle with Wally to
see that we've got everything covered. And we won't likely be staying
overnight (we live an hour south, so it's hard to justify the hotel fees,
plus we have a dog who isn't welcome and we don't like to leave her). We may
just be there for one day, but hopefully both.

Pam


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Nancy

messages.subject: homeschooling conferences
messages.msgSnippet: There are three conferences coming up at which I m speaking, and others here are speaking at one or another of them too.  So I thought maybe it would be good
messages.messageBody:
There are three conferences coming up at which I'm speaking, and others here
are speaking at one or another of them too. So I thought maybe it would be
good to ask this thoughtful group for suggestions on what is, would be, has
been helpful to you at an in-person presentation.

Different people like different things too. Some like a workshop at which
they're directly addressed, and given something to hold or do or say. Others
like anonymity where they listen in quiet stillness (on the outside, anyway).

Is there anyone on this list who was in Long Beach last spring when I did the
thing with the kitchen timer and the six topics which were ended at ten
minutes by the timer? I'm thinking of doing that one again, maybe.

I'm thinking that in South Carolina I should do the "That's Not Educational"
game that I've done sometimes before, where people name things and I tell
them what learning opportunities could be made of them. If I can't, they get
a prize.

Are there other conferences than these three that some of you are attending
or participating in?

Saturday, April 6, 2002, Bay Shore, Long Beach, California

August 17-19, 2002, HSC Home=Education Conference Sacramento, California

Oct 11, 12, 13, 2002, Live & Learn Conference in Columbia, South Carolina.


Sandra

P.S.
For those who might be here who are or were involved in the cooperative
MindFull conference in September in Fort Worth, I've withdrawn from
participation. I'm sorry it didn't work out differently. Before I signed on
I was told it would be open to others up to the last minute, for locals who
found out about it late. Then it was closed entirely. There were a few
other problems, which perhaps could just be written off as having to do with
my own pushy personality, but I'm not going to subject five kids to a drive
into the heat of Texas for that (not to mention hotel meals for six people
for three days, gas, risking lives, etc.) And the teenaged boys were SO
realistic about the "opportunity" to meet lots of other homeschooled teens.
They said if they liked them a lot it would be frustrating that they wouldn't
get to see them more, and if they didn't like them much it would be
frustrating that they'd gone so far and were stuck there three days. Pretty
smart kids.
